subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Question, How to get the U sound in "Up"?
msgSnippet: I don t have the capability of recording presently and haven t been involved with MP3. But it sounds interesting so I would encourage any of our group who does
messageBody:
I don't have the capability of recording presently and haven't been involved with MP3.  But it sounds interesting so I would encourage any of our group who does to participate in this with you.

Regarding your rant:  I have also read these tiresome posts on "up" vs. "ado", and they strike me as pointless as well.  I tried responding to this once, but it was futile.  The people on the Shavian site seem to welcome discussing this ad infinitum just as theologians in the middle ages debated how many angels could stand on the head of a pin.  Perhaps, I'm thick, but I really don't hear any significant difference between what they insist are two separate two vowels.  I pointed out that the dictionary uses the same schwa symbol for all these words they are giving as examples, but this does not interest them apparently.

I do not understand your reference to the dictionary as I do not know what the pronoun "its" referred to in "as though no one could look up its actual meaning."

I also don't understand the comment "I sound OK to me excuses..."  My position is that most of us have no trouble understanding others speaking English (unless it is a very obscure accent) and that there should be no requirement that people spell words in QS according to some arbitrary authority such as a dictionary as I do not believe the number of spellings that vary would be so great as to impede understanding.

I must admit I have seen QS and Shavian written with vowels that seem very peculiar to me.  In most instances, I assume this is from people with little experience in QS or Shaivan, and they are inaccurately representing their speech.  Even so, this doesn't impede comprehension, it just looks odd.

Paige Gabhart

HeyMister57@... wrote:

 Rant on >>>
This is soooo dumb.

I have written numerous website owners. I have listened to the now tedious
questions about "up," the endless "I sound OK to me," excuses, and the huge
silence regarding the word "dictionary" as though no one could look up its
actual meaning.  This has been going on for too many years.

I have resisted chiding, but I'm at the end of my patience.
<<< Rant off

Is there anyone - other than myself - that can record their voice pronouncing
the key words that define the Read letters? Perhaps encode it as an MP3?

I'll exchange a recording for a recording.  Anyone up for it?
